Saila Behari Singh Versus Commissioner Of Income-Tax
High Court of Judicature at Calcutta
Judges THE HONOURABLE CHIEF JUSTICE MR. HARRIES & THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE
ADVOCATES APPEARED:For the Appearing Parties : J.C.Pal,Panchanan Pal,Priti
(1) THIS is a reference under <PV>Section 66 (i) </PV>, <LG>Income-tax Act, </LG> at
the instance of the assessee in which the following questions are propounded for the
<IS>(1) Whether the legal obligation created by the deed was rightly construed by
the Tribunal as a private religious trust? If so, (2) Whether the last paragraph of
Section 4 (3)  (xii) enumerated above governs both the words "trust" and; "other
legal obligations" as mentioned in   Section 4 (3)  (i) or only "trusts"?</IS>
(2) THE income sought to be assessed in this case was income from property which
admittedly was devoted to religious purposes. The only difference between the
parties was whether these properties which produced the income, which were
admittedly debutter properties, were properties held in trust for deities or
properties dedicated to the deities. The question arose upon the true construction
to be given to the phrase "held under trust or other legal obligation wholly for
religious or charitable purposes" appearing inSection 4 (3) (i), Income-tax Act. To
this sub section there is appended an Explanation which is in these terms :
"in this sub-section, 'charitable purpose' includes relief of the poor, education,
medical relief, and the advancement of any other object of general public utility
but nothing contained in Clause (i), Clause (ia) or Clause (ii) shall operate to
exempt from the provisions of this Act that part of the income of a private
religious trust which does not enure for the benefit of the public. "
(3) IT will be seen that although <HD>under  Section 4 (3) (i) income derived from
property held under trusts or other legal obligation wholly for religious or
charitable purposes is exempt from taxation, the Explanation makes it clear that
only that part of an income of a private religious trust is exempted which enures
for the benefit of the public and that part which does not enure for the benefit of
the public is not exempt from taxation.</HD>
(4) IT will be seen that what is not exempt from taxation is that part of the income
of a private religious trust which does not enure for the benefit of the public and
the question arose in an earlier case as to whether the words "private religious
trust" were wide enough to cover all debutter property. This Court held in the case
of Sree Sree Iswar Gopal Jew v. Commr. of Income-tax, West Bengal, (1950) 18 I. T.
R. 743 (Cal.), that where the income arose from property dedicated to a deity as
opposed to property held by trustees in trust for a deity, the provisions exempting
(withdrawing the exemption from?) such portions of the income as did not enure for
the benefit of the public had no application, and that where the income arose from
dedicated property as opposed to property held on trust for the deity, the whole of
the income was exempt from taxation.
(5) IT appears clear that the Appellate Tribunal regarded this income as income
arising from property dedicated to deities rather than to property held in trust for
deities. But in the view of the Appellate Tribunal it mattered not as no distinction
could be drawn between property held under a private religious trust and property
dedicated to a private deity. The case of course was decided by the Appellate
Tribunal before the decision of this Court to which I have made reference.
(6) MR. Pal admits that if the income in this case arose from property dedicated to
deities, no distinction could be drawn between this case and the authority of this
Court which I have cited. However his contention is that the income in this case was
income derived from property held on trust for deities and not from property
dedicated to the deities. It seems from an Arpannama executed by the Shebaits on
21/11/1910 that the properties of Arpannama recite that a document is necessary for
"but although the aforesaid properties are really ancient debutter properties as
there is no written deed of Arpannama and in order to remove our apprehension that
in future someone might treat the aforesaid debutter properties or any portion
thereof as secular properties we execute this deed of Arpannama and promise that the
aforesaid properties are real debutter properties and that we both the brothers are
at present absolute Maliks (owners) of the same as sole shebaits. "
<HD>From this recital it appears clear that the properties had been devoted to
religious purposes for a considerable time. They are ancient debutter properties in
which there was no written deed of Arpannama. That would strongly suggest that these
were properties which had been dedicated to the deities in the past. Further it
appears to me that there are other words used earlier which make it clear that these
debutter properties were properties dedicated to the deities rather than properties
held in trust for the deities. </HD>It is stated that certain expenses of the
deities"which are being incurred to carry on the aforesaid 'sheba, Mahotsab etc. ,
or to make new construction and repairs in respect of Sree Mandir (temple),
Natyasala (Auditorium), kitchen and stores etc. , the properties described in detail
in the schedule given below have been dedicated for the same from the time of our
ancestors as well as in our time. "
(7) IF that is a correct translation there can be no question that the properties
were regarded as having been dedicated to the deities and that the income therefrom
was to be devoted to the worship of the deity.
(8) MR. Pal however has contended that the translation is not accurate and that a
more literal translation would have been that the properties had been earmarked for
the deities. On the other hand my learned brother is satisfied that the translation
does express the meaning of the original Arpannama. Even if the appropriate
translation was "earmarked" that would be inappropriate for the creation of a trust
in the English fashion, but would be more appropriate for the dedication or the
creating of a legal obligation which is not a "trust" in the true sense of the word.
(9) <HD>THIS deed of Arpannama of course cannot create a trust. It merely recites
that the properties were debutter and had been debutter for a long time. The
executants recite that they are the shebaits and Mr. Pal lays great stress on the
words they use namely, that they were "absolute Maliks of the same as sole shebaits.
" It appears to me that all that that means is that they are the shebaits and of
course have the sole management of the property and are in effect, if not in law,
the owners for the time being. However, it is seen that a distinction is drawn
between the ownership of property and the office of she-bait, because it is later
stated that the owners of Ukhra Estate for the time being will be the shebaits. It
seems to me that the Arpannama for what it is worth, shows that the properties were
debutter and were not held in trust for the deities, but were properties which had
been dedicated or given to the deities. The income from such properties cannot be
said to be income arising from a private religious trust, as the word "trust" had a
definite meaning and dedicated properties are not in the strict sense properties
held in trust or properties which are the subject-matter of a trust. Once it is held
that these properties were dedicated properties then the earlier case to which I
have made reference admittedly applies and I would, therefore, answer the questions
submitted as follows: Question (1) is answered in the negative. Question (2) is
answered as follows: The last paragraph ofSection 4 (3) (xii), Income-tax Act
governs only the word "trust" and does not govern the words "other legal
obligations" which appear in   Section 4 (3)  (i) of the Act.</HD>
(10) THE assessees are entitled to the costs of these proceedings. Certified for two

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a vital subfield of Artificial Intelligence (AI) that
enables computers to interpret, understand, and generate human language. One of the most
popular applications of NLP is Sentiment Analysis, which involves identifying and
categorizing opinions expressed in text to determine whether the writer's attitude is positive,
In the modern digital era, vast volumes of textual data are generated every second through
social media posts, blogs, online product reviews, news articles, and customer feedback. This
explosion of digital content has made it increasingly important for businesses, governments,
and researchers to understand and interpret public opinions and emotions expressed through
these texts. The ability to automatically extract subjective information from text and analyze
people's attitudes and sentiments toward a topic has become essential for decision-making
Sentiment analysis primarily helps in determining whether a given piece of text expresses a
positive, negative, or neutral sentiment. For example, online customer reviews such as “The
phone’s battery life is excellent” would be classified as positive, while “The service was
terrible and disappointing” would be categorized as negative. More sophisticated systems can
go beyond polarity detection to identify specific emotions like happiness, anger, or frustration
and can even detect sarcasm, although this remains a challenging task.
It is extensively used in social media monitoring, brand management, market research,
customer service optimization, political analysis, and even public health monitoring. It seeks

2.1 WHAT IS SENTIMENT ANALYSIS?
Sentiment analysis, also known as opinion mining, is a computational technique that involves
identifying, extracting, and classifying opinions or emotions expressed in textual data. It
determines whether the expressed sentiment is positive, negative, or neutral. Sentiment analysis
is a key area of research in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and text analytics, as it enables
systems to interpret subjective information embedded within large volumes of textual data
generated on digital platforms.
With the explosive growth of social media, online reviews, forums, and blogs, the need to
automatically analyze opinions and sentiments has become essential for businesses,
governments, and organizations to make informed decisions.
2.2 OBJECTIVES OF SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
The main objectives of sentiment analysis are:
➢ To Determine Polarity: Classifying text as positive, negative, or neutral.
➢ To Detect Emotions: Identifying emotions like happiness, anger, sadness, or fear.
➢ To Identify Opinions: Understanding opinions expressed towards particular products,
➢ To Extract Subjective Information: Distinguishing between objective facts and
➢ To Support Decision-Making: Providing valuable insights for marketing, customer
service, product improvements, and public relations.
2.3 IMPORTANCE OF SENTIMENT ANALYSIS IN NLP
Sentiment analysis holds significant importance in NLP because:
➢ It converts unstructured text data into meaningful, actionable insights.
➢ It helps businesses monitor brand reputation and customer satisfaction.
➢ Political analysts use it to gauge public opinions during elections or policy
➢ It enables real-time monitoring of public sentiment on social media.
➢ Healthcare organizations can analyze patient reviews and feedback for service
2.4 LEVELS OF SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Sentiment analysis can be performed at different granularity levels:
Document-Level Sentiment Analysis: Determines the overall sentiment of an entire
Sentence-Level Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes sentiment expressed in individual
Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis: Identifies sentiments towards specific features or
Phrase-Level Sentiment Analysis: Detects sentiment polarity in specific phrases or
2.5 SENTIMENT ANALYSIS PROCESS FLOW
The typical process flow of sentiment analysis involves several key stages:
1. Data Collection: Gathering text data from sources like social media, reviews, or
2. Text Pre-processing: Cleaning the data by removing special characters, stop words,
3. Feature Extraction: Converting text into numerical features using methods like TF-
IDF, word embeddings, or bag-of-words.
4. Sentiment Classification: Using lexicon-based, machine learning, or deep learning
5. Results Interpretation: Analyzing and visualizing sentiment insights for decision-
Sentiment analysis is not limited to merely identifying whether text is positive, negative, or
neutral. The nature and purpose of the analysis determine the granularity of sentiment
detection. The sentiment analysis can be divided into several types. Each type plays a
significant role in practical applications like customer feedback analysis, political sentiment
mining, product review summarization, and social media trend analysis.
3.1 DOCUMENT-LEVEL SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Document-level sentiment analysis determines the overall sentiment conveyed in an entire
document, treating it as a single entity.

3.2 SENTENCE-LEVEL SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Sentence-level analysis focuses on identifying the sentiment expressed in individual sentences.
"The camera quality is superb, but the battery drains quickly."
"The camera quality is superb." → Positive
"The battery drains quickly." → Negative
3.3 ASPECT-BASED SENTIMENT ANALYSIS (ABSA)
Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis identifies sentiments expressed toward specific features or
"The screen resolution is amazing, but the battery life is disappointing."
Aspect: Screen resolution → Positive
Aspect: Battery life → Negative
3.4 COMPARATIVE SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Comparative sentiment analysis identifies sentiments when comparisons are made between
"This phone is better than the previous model."
Previous model: Negative (implied)
Emotion detection identifies specific emotions expressed in text rather than just polarity.
"I’m thrilled with my new job!"
TECHNIQUES AND APPROACHES FOR SENTIMENT
4.1 MACHINE LEARNING-BASED APPROACH
In machine learning-based sentiment analysis, sentiment detection is treated as a classification
problem. Here, a model is trained on a labeled dataset containing text and its corresponding
sentiment labels. Once trained, the model can predict the sentiment of new, unseen texts.
Common machine learning algorithms include:
It uses probabilistic reasoning based on the frequency of words.
• Support Vector Machines (SVM)
It finds an optimal boundary (hyperplane) to separate different sentiment classes.
• Decision Trees and Logistic Regression
These are also widely used for simple sentiment classification tasks.
4.2 DEEP LEARNING-BASED APPROACH
With the growth of big data and advancements in computing power, deep learning has
become a preferred technique for sentiment analysis. Unlike traditional models, deep
learning can automatically extract features and learn complex patterns.
Common deep learning models include:
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN)
Suitable for sequential data like text, as it remembers previous inputs.
Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) Networks
An advanced form of RNN capable of handling long-term dependencies.
A simpler alternative to LSTM with comparable performance.
These models can process text sequences effectively, making them capable of capturing
context and sentiment in long sentences.
Hybrid systems combine multiple techniques to leverage the strengths of each. For
example, a system might use a lexicon-based approach for known sentiment words and a
machine learning classifier for ambiguous or domain-specific terms. These systems often
achieve higher accuracy and robustness, especially in real-world applications involving
The rule-based approach is one of the earliest techniques in sentiment analysis. It relies on
a set of manually crafted linguistic rules and sentiment lexicons containing positive,
negative, and neutral words. The system determines the sentiment of a text by counting the
occurrences  of  these  words  and  applying  predefined  grammatical  rules.
For example, words like good, excellent, and amazing are labeled as positive, while bad,
poor, and terrible are marked negative. Although simple to implement, this method
struggles with understanding context, sarcasm, and domain-specific terms. It also lacks
scalability when dealing with large datasets or frequently changing language trends.
4.5 APPLICATIONS OF SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Business Intelligence: Understand customer opinions, reviews, and feedback.
Political Analysis: Gauge public opinion during elections.
Market Research: Monitor brand reputation.
Social Media Monitoring: Track social trends, controversies, and public reactions.
Healthcare: Analyze patient reviews and feedback.
4.6 CHALLENGES IN SENTIMENT ANALYSIS
Sarcasm and Irony Detection: Hard to detect when literal meaning differs from
Context Sensitivity: Words may have different sentiments in different contexts.
Multilingual Sentiment Analysis: Requires handling multiple languages and dialects.
Handling Negations and Modifiers: Phrases like "not bad" may be tricky to interpret.
CASE STUDIES AND REAL-WORLD EXAMPLES
CASE STUDY 1: SENTIMENT ANALYSIS OF TWITTER DATA
Twitter, as one of the most active social media platforms, has become a valuable source of
public opinion and real-time reactions to global events, product launches, political debates, and
crisis situations. The platform generates millions of tweets daily, containing public sentiments,
personal opinions, and spontaneous feedback. Sentiment analysis of Twitter data has gained
significant attention for its ability to provide immediate insights into public mood and emerging
trends. One widely referenced case study involves the use of sentiment analysis tools during
the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak. The real-time sentiment analysis of Twitter data provided
actionable insights that guided decision-making processes, public health communication
strategies, and awareness campaigns. It showcased the potential of sentiment analysis in
handling crisis situations by analyzing large-scale, real-time social media data to capture public
CASE STUDY 2: SENTIMENT ANALYSIS IN E-COMMERCE PRODUCT
One of the most prominent applications of sentiment analysis is within the e-commerce sector,
where companies utilize this technology to analyze customer reviews and feedback. A notable
example is the deployment of sentiment analysis systems by Amazon, one of the world’s largest
online marketplaces. Amazon processes millions of product reviews posted by customers daily.
Through the integration of sentiment analysis algorithms, the company can automatically
classify reviews as positive, negative, or neutral, offering prospective buyers an aggregated
view of product sentiment. These sentiment classifications are displayed on product pages in
the form of summary ratings and customer feedback trends. Additionally, aspect-based
sentiment analysis is employed to identify sentiments towards specific product features such
as durability, delivery service, packaging, and usability. For instance, a customer review
stating, "The product quality is excellent, but delivery was delayed," is dissected into multiple
aspects, recognizing positive sentiment for quality and negative sentiment for delivery service
In conclusion that sentiment analysis has emerged as one of the most significant applications
within the field of Natural Language Processing (NLP), offering valuable insights into human
opinions, emotions, and attitudes expressed through text. As digital communication continues
to proliferate, the ability to automatically analyze sentiments in online reviews, social media
posts, news articles, and various other forms of textual content has become crucial for
businesses, governments, and researchers alike. This seminar report has explored the
fundamental concepts, techniques, types, and applications of sentiment analysis, providing a
comprehensive overview of how this technology functions and where it is headed in the future.
The practical applications of sentiment analysis were also reviewed, revealing its widespread
usage in areas such as marketing analytics, political opinion tracking, product review analysis,
customer service enhancement, and social media monitoring. The ability of sentiment analysis
systems to capture public opinion trends in real-time has proven to be a valuable asset for
organizations seeking to enhance customer satisfaction, manage brand reputation, and make
informed decisions based on public sentiment.
In summary, sentiment analysis represents a rapidly growing and dynamic area of research
within NLP, offering both significant challenges and promising opportunities. As technological
advancements continue to reshape the landscape of natural language understanding, sentiment
analysis is set to play an increasingly vital role in interpreting human emotions, behaviors, and
societal trends in the digital age.

religious or charitable purposes" appearing inSection 4 (3) (i), Income-tax Act. To

but nothing contained in Clause (i), Clause (ia) or Clause (ii) shall operate to
exempt from the provisions of this Act that part of the income of a private
religious trust which does not enure for the benefit of the public. "
(3) IT will be seen that although <HD>under  Section 4 (3) (i) income derived from
property held under trusts or other legal obligation wholly for religious or
charitable purposes is exempt from taxation, the Explanation makes it clear that
only that part of an income of a private religious trust is exempted which enures
for the benefit of the public and that part which does not enure for the benefit of
the public is not exempt from taxation.</HD>

of a private religious trust which does not enure for the benefit of the public and
the question arose in an earlier case as to whether the words "private religious
trust" were wide enough to cover all debutter property. This Court held in the case
of Sree Sree Iswar Gopal Jew v. Commr. of Income-tax, West Bengal, (1950) 18 I. T.

opposed to property held by trustees in trust for a deity, the provisions exempting
(withdrawing the exemption from?) such portions of the income as did not enure for
the benefit of the public had no application, and that where the income arose from
dedicated property as opposed to property held on trust for the deity, the whole of
the income was exempt from taxation.

arising from property dedicated to deities rather than to property held in trust for
deities. But in the view of the Appellate Tribunal it mattered not as no distinction
could be drawn between property held under a private religious trust and property
dedicated to a private deity. The case of course was decided by the Appellate
Tribunal before the decision of this Court to which I have made reference.

deities, no distinction could be drawn between this case and the authority of this

dedicated to the deities. It seems from an Arpannama executed by the Shebaits on

"but although the aforesaid properties are really ancient debutter properties as
there is no written deed of Arpannama and in order to remove our apprehension that
in future someone might treat the aforesaid debutter properties or any portion
thereof as secular properties we execute this deed of Arpannama and promise that the
aforesaid properties are real debutter properties and that we both the brothers are
at present absolute Maliks (owners) of the same as sole shebaits. "

religious purposes for a considerable time. They are ancient debutter properties in
which there was no written deed of Arpannama. That would strongly suggest that these
were properties which had been dedicated to the deities in the past. Further it
appears to me that there are other words used earlier which make it clear that these
debutter properties were properties dedicated to the deities rather than properties
held in trust for the deities. </HD>It is stated that certain expenses of the
deities"which are being incurred to carry on the aforesaid 'sheba, Mahotsab etc. ,
or to make new construction and repairs in respect of Sree Mandir (temple),
Natyasala (Auditorium), kitchen and stores etc. , the properties described in detail
in the schedule given below have been dedicated for the same from the time of our
ancestors as well as in our time. "
(7) IF that is a correct translation there can be no question that the properties
were regarded as having been dedicated to the deities and that the income therefrom
was to be devoted to the worship of the deity.

more literal translation would have been that the properties had been earmarked for
the deities. On the other hand my learned brother is satisfied that the translation
does express the meaning of the original Arpannama. Even if the appropriate
translation was "earmarked" that would be inappropriate for the creation of a trust
in the English fashion, but would be more appropriate for the dedication or the
creating of a legal obligation which is not a "trust" in the true sense of the word.
(9) <HD>THIS deed of Arpannama of course cannot create a trust. It merely recites
that the properties were debutter and had been debutter for a long time. The
executants recite that they are the shebaits and Mr. Pal lays great stress on the
words they use namely, that they were "absolute Maliks of the same as sole shebaits.
" It appears to me that all that that means is that they are the shebaits and of
course have the sole management of the property and are in effect, if not in law,
the owners for the time being. However, it is seen that a distinction is drawn
between the ownership of property and the office of she-bait, because it is later
stated that the owners of Ukhra Estate for the time being will be the shebaits. It
seems to me that the Arpannama for what it is worth, shows that the properties were
debutter and were not held in trust for the deities, but were properties which had
been dedicated or given to the deities. The income from such properties cannot be
said to be income arising from a private religious trust, as the word "trust" had a
definite meaning and dedicated properties are not in the strict sense properties
held in trust or properties which are the subject-matter of a trust. Once it is held
that these properties were dedicated properties then the earlier case to which I
have made reference admittedly applies and I would, therefore, answer the questions
submitted as follows: Question (1) is answered in the negative. Question (2) is
answered as follows: The last paragraph ofSection 4 (3) (xii), Income-tax Act
governs only the word "trust" and does not govern the words "other legal
obligations" which appear in   Section 4 (3)  (i) of the Act.</HD>

<FC>(1) THIS is an appln for leave to appeal to the S. C. from an appellate decree
of this Ct dated 10-5-1950, affirming a decree of a learned Subordinate Judge made
(2) THE pltfs brought a suit for rent of a patni for the years 1350 to the Pous
kist, 1352 B. S. at the annual rate of Rs. 5368/6/- with certain cesses. The
defence to the suit was that the pltfs were not entitled to 16 annas of the
landlord's interest, that a good portion of the land comprised in the tenure had
been lost by diluvion and as such the defts were entitled to a substantial
abatement of rent, and there was a further plea of payment.
(3) THE learned Subordinate Judge held that the pltfs were entitled to the 16 annas
of the landlord's interest and that there had been no payment. On the question of
diluvion the Subordinate Judge held that the deft had failed to prove what
abatement in the rent he was entitled to.
(4) BEFORE a Bench of this Ct the only point argued was that the learned
Subordinate Judge was wrong on this question of diluvion. This Ct was satisfied
that certain land had been lost by, diluvion, but on the other hand it was of
opinion that no abatement could be made in the rent because the original area of
the patni was unknown and therefore it was impossible to say how much should be
allowed per acre in abatement. In the result the appeal was dismissed in this Ct.
(5) MR. Mukherjee on behalf of the proposed applt contended that the value of the
suit and of the proposed appeal are over Rs. 20,000/ ?. He has pointed out that the
words in Article 133 (1) (a) of the Constitution differ from the words in   Section
110 of the C. P. C. Under Article 133 (1) (a) what has to be considered is the
value of the subject matter of the dispute in the Ct of first instance and still in
dispute on appeal. Mr. Mukherjee has contended that the value of the dispute in the
Ct of first instance was over Rs. 20,000/ ?.
<HD>(6) THE suit was a rent suit and the claim was for Rs. 12,800/- approximately
and it appears to me quite clear that that was the value of the dispute. The
defence was that the patnidars were entitled to an abatement and therefore liable
to pay less than the amount claimed. It seems to me that the value of the subject
matter of the dispute at its highest was Rs 12,800/- approximately, and if effect
was given to the defence, the value of the claim would be substantially reduced.
Mr. Mukherjee however has contended that a capitalised value should be given to his
defence. For example, if he claimed that he was entitled to an abatement of, say
Rs. 100/- a year, that claim should be capitalised at, for example, fifteen years'
purchase which would make the value of that claim Rs 1500/ ?. That, according to
Mr. Mukherjee the capitalised value of the defence as it were, also forms the
(7) IT seems to me that the dispute in this case was whether or not the pltfs were
entitled to rent at the rate claimed for the period claimed. No claim was made as
to the future and therefore what was to occur in the future was not and could not
be in dispute. It seems to me quite impossible to capitalise, as it were, the value
of the defence and include it in the value of the dispute. The value of the dispute
in this case could not possibly exceed Rs. 12,800/- and therefore no leave can be
given unless the case is one that falls within Article 133 (1) (c) of the
(8) THE point of law as to whether in the circumstances abatement of rent could be
claimed was found in favour of the proposed applt. All that Mr. Mukherjee can
complain of is that the learned Judges were wrong in holding that the proposed
applt had failed to prove the area comprised in the patni which he had to do before
the extent of the abatement could be arrived at. Mr. Mukherjee has pointed out that
in the plaint the lands comprised in the patni are described with reference to
khatians of the Cadastral Survey. He contends that there is an admission that the
lands are as described and defined in the Cadastral Survey. Mr. Sen who appears for
the resps has pointed out that the Bengal Tenancy Act requires plaints in a rent
suit to refer to the Record-of-Rights and the survey documents and therefore there
was no admission that the area of the lands comprised in the patni was the area as
now shown in the Cadastral Survey. The patni was of the year 1913, whereas the
survey was considerably later. There was no evidence to show that the Mouza as
surveyed later was the same as it was at the date of this lease. Certain Revenue
papers showed one area, whereas the survey records showed another. In those
circumstances the Ct held that the proposed applt had failed to show the area of
the patni, and that being so no abatement could be granted.
(9) WHETHER the pleadings as drafted amounted to an admission or not cannot, I
think, be said to be a point of any great public or private importance and is not
the sort of question which would entitle us to certify this as a fit case for
appeal. Mr. Mukherjee has to concede that unless he can bring the case under
Article 133 (1) of the Constitution no leave could be given. Even if it could be
brought under Article 133 (1), I do not think it could be possibly said that the
case involved a substantive point off law which would be necessary before leave
could be given in the case of a decree of affirmance, even though the value of the
dispute was over Rs. 20,000. 00.
<DP>(10) IN my view this appln must fail and I would dismiss</DP> it with costs the
hearing fee being assessed at four gold mohurs. Let the counter-affidavit filed in
Ct today, be kept on the record.</HD>
